en.headerSubtitle: Celebrating the lives and legacies of India's inspiring figures.

en.footerDisclaimer: All images and content are for educational and tribute purposes only.
sachinMajorAchievementsShort: 100 International Centuries: The only player in history to score 100 international centuries.
2011 Cricket World Cup Winner: A pivotal member of the Indian team that won the World Cup.
sachinMajorAchievementsFull: 100 International Centuries: The only player in history to score 100 international centuries.
2011 Cricket World Cup Winner: A pivotal member of the Indian team that won the World Cup.
Highest Run-Scorer: Holds the record for most runs in both Test and One Day International (ODI) cricket.
Bharat Ratna: Awarded India's highest civilian honour in 2014.
First Male to Score ODI Double Century: Achieved this feat against South Africa in 2010.
sachinTimelineShort: 1989: Made Test and ODI debut against Pakistan.
sachinTimelineFull: 1989: Made Test and ODI debut against Pakistan.
2007: Surpassed Brian Lara to become the highest run-scorer in Test cricket.
2011: Won the Cricket World Cup with India.
2013: Retired from all forms of cricket.
en.sachinAutobiographyShort: "**Playing It My Way**" (2014) is his widely acclaimed autobiography.
en.sachinAutobiographyFull: "**Playing It My Way**" (2014) is his widely acclaimed autobiography, chronicling his journey from a young cricket prodigy to a global icon, offering insights into his personal life and illustrious career.
maryKomMajorAchievementsShort: Six-time World Amateur Boxing Champion: The only female to achieve this feat.
Olympic Bronze Medal: Won bronze at the 2012 London Olympics.
maryKomMajorAchievementsFull: Six-time World Amateur Boxing Champion: The only female to achieve this feat.
Olympic Bronze Medal: Won bronze at the 2012 London Olympics.
Asian Games Gold Medal: Secured gold at the 2014 Incheon Asian Games.
Commonwealth Games Gold Medal: Won gold at the 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games.
Padma Vibhushan: Awarded India's second-highest civilian honour in 2020.
maryKomTimelineShort: 2001: Won her first World Boxing Championship silver medal.
2012: Won bronze medal at the London Olympics.
maryKomTimelineFull: 2001: Won her first World Boxing Championship silver medal.
2002-2010: Won 5 consecutive World Championship gold medals.
2012: Won bronze medal at the London Olympics.
2014: Won gold at the Asian Games.
2018: Won her record sixth World Championship gold medal.
2020: Awarded the Padma Vibhushan.
en.maryKomAutobiographyFull: "**Unbreakable**" (2013) is her inspiring autobiography, detailing her struggles, triumphs, and journey to becoming a boxing legend while balancing motherhood.
ratanTataMajorAchievementsShort: Transformed Tata Group: Led the conglomerate through major global acquisitions.
Pioneered Tata Nano: Launched the world's most affordable car.
ratanTataMajorAchievementsFull: Transformed Tata Group: Led the conglomerate through major global acquisitions, including Tetley Tea, Jaguar Land Rover, and Corus Steel.
Pioneered Tata Nano: Launched the world's most affordable car, Tata Nano, making car ownership accessible to many.
Increased Group Revenue: During his chairmanship, Tata Group's revenues grew exponentially.
Padma Vibhushan: Awarded India's second-highest civilian honour in 2008.
Philanthropic Efforts: Known for his commitment to philanthropy and ethical business practices.
ratanTataTimelineShort: 2008: Tata Motors acquires Jaguar Land Rover.
ratanTataTimelineFull: 2008: Tata Motors acquires Jaguar Land Rover; Tata Nano launched.
2012: Stepped down as Chairman of Tata Sons.
en.ratanTataAutobiographyShort: While not a traditional autobiography, his life and work are extensively documented in various biographies.
en.ratanTataAutobiographyFull: While not a traditional autobiography, his life and work are extensively documented in "**The Wit & Wisdom of Ratan Tata**" and numerous biographies, highlighting his vision and leadership.
kiranShawMajorAchievementsShort: Founder of Biocon: Built Biocon from a garage startup.
Biotech Pioneer: Instrumental in putting India on the global biotech map.
kiranShawMajorAchievementsFull: Founder of Biocon: Built Biocon from a garage startup into a leading global biopharmaceutical company.
Biotech Pioneer: Instrumental in putting India on the global biotech map, focusing on affordable healthcare.
Prominent Female Entrepreneur: Recognized globally as one of the most powerful and influential women in business.
Padma Bhushan: Awarded India's third-highest civilian honour in 2005.
Forbes "World's 100 Most Powerful Women": Consistently featured on this prestigious list.
kiranShawTimelineShort: 1978: Founded Biocon in her garage in Bengaluru.
2004: Biocon becomes the first Indian biotech company to go public.
kiranShawTimelineFull: 1978: Founded Biocon in her garage in Bengaluru.
2004: Biocon becomes the first Indian biotech company to go public.
2005: Awarded the Padma Bhushan.
2014: Featured in Forbes' "The World's 100 Most Powerful Women".
2019: Elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
en.kiranShawAutobiographyShort: While she hasn't published a dedicated autobiography, her journey is a prominent part of many books.
en.kiranShawAutobiographyFull: While she hasn't published a dedicated autobiography, her journey is a prominent part of many books on Indian entrepreneurship and innovation, highlighting her pioneering spirit.
en.kiranShawWikipedia: ЁЯУЦ Kiran Mazumdar Shaw on Wikipedia
tagoreMajorAchievementsShort: Nobel Prize in Literature (1913): The first non-European to win a Nobel Prize.
Composed National Anthems: Authored the national anthems of India and Bangladesh.
tagoreMajorAchievementsFull: Nobel Prize in Literature (1913): The first non-European to win a Nobel Prize, awarded for his profound and sensitive, fresh and beautiful verse, especially "Gitanjali".
Composed National Anthems: Authored the national anthems of India ("Jana Gana Mana") and Bangladesh ("Amar Shonar Bangla").
Founded Visva-Bharati University: Established an experimental school at Santiniketan, which evolved into a renowned university.
Prolific Writer: Penned over 2,000 songs, numerous poems, novels, short stories, essays, and plays.
Modernized Bengali Art and Literature: Revolutionized Bengali literature and Indian art with contextual modernism.
tagoreTimelineShort: 1913: Awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
tagoreTimelineFull: 1901: Established the Brahmacharya Ashram, which later became Visva-Bharati University.
1913: Awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
1919: Renounced his knighthood in protest of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre.
en.tagoreAutobiographyFull: "**My Reminiscences**" (1912), originally "Jivan Smriti" in Bengali, offers a vivid account of his early life and experiences that shaped his literary genius.
cvRamanMajorAchievementsShort: Nobel Prize in Physics (1930): Awarded for his work on the scattering of light.
Raman Effect: Discovered that deflected light changes wavelength.
cvRamanMajorAchievementsFull: Nobel Prize in Physics (1930): Awarded for his work on the scattering of light and for the discovery of the effect named after him (Raman Effect).
Raman Effect: Discovered that when light traverses a transparent material, some of the deflected light changes wavelength and amplitude.
Established Research Institutions: Made significant contributions to science in India, fostering a strong scientific environment.
First Indian Director of IISc: Became the first Indian Director of the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore.
Bharat Ratna: Conferred with India's highest civilian award in 1954.
cvRamanTimelineShort: 1930: Awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics.
cvRamanTimelineFull: 1917: Appointed Palit Professor of Physics at the University of Calcutta.
1930: Awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics.
en.cvRamanAutobiographyShort: C.V. Raman did not write a formal autobiography, but his life and work are extensively documented.
en.cvRamanAutobiographyFull: C.V. Raman did not write a formal autobiography, but his life and work are extensively documented in numerous scientific and biographical accounts, emphasizing his groundbreaking contributions to physics.
gandhiMajorAchievementsShort: Indian Independence Movement: Led India to independence from British rule.
Satyagraha: Developed the philosophy of nonviolent resistance.
gandhiMajorAchievementsFull: Indian Independence Movement: Led India to independence from British rule through nonviolent civil disobedience.
Satyagraha: Developed the philosophy of nonviolent resistance, inspiring civil rights movements globally.
Dandi March (Salt March): A landmark act of civil disobedience against the British salt monopoly.
Quit India Movement: Launched a mass movement demanding an end to British rule.
Promoted Social Harmony: Campaigned against untouchability and advocated for Hindu-Muslim unity.
gandhiTimelineShort: 1915: Returned to India and joined the nationalist movement.
gandhiTimelineFull: 1893: Moved to South Africa, where he developed Satyagraha.
1915: Returned to India and joined the nationalist movement.
en.gandhiAutobiographyShort: "**The Story of My Experiments with Truth**" (1925-1929) is his seminal autobiography.
en.gandhiAutobiographyFull: "**The Story of My Experiments with Truth**" (1925-1929) is his seminal autobiography, offering deep insights into his moral and spiritual development and the evolution of his Satyagraha philosophy.
en.apjKalamFigCaption: Avul Pakir Jainulabdeen Abdul Kalam (1931 тАУ 2015)
apjKalamMajorAchievementsShort: 11th President of India (2002-2007): Known as the "People's President".
"Missile Man of India": Played a leading role in India's missile programs.
apjKalamMajorAchievementsFull: 11th President of India (2002-2007): Known as the "People's President" for his accessible and inspiring tenure.
"Missile Man of India": Played a leading role in the development of India's ballistic missile and nuclear weapons programs.
Scientist and Engineer: Key figure in the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) and Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO).
Bharat Ratna: Conferred with India's highest civilian award in 1997.
Prolific Author and Educator: Wrote several inspiring books and dedicated his post-presidency to education.
apjKalamTimelineShort: 1980s: Spearheaded the Integrated Guided Missile Development Program (IGMDP).
2002: Elected as the 11th President of India.
apjKalamTimelineFull: 1980s: Spearheaded the Integrated Guided Missile Development Program (IGMDP).
1992-1999: Served as Chief Scientific Adviser to the Prime Minister.
2002: Elected as the 11th President of India.
2015: Passed away while delivering a lecture.
en.apjKalamAutobiographyShort: "**Wings of Fire**" (1999) is his inspiring autobiography.
en.apjKalamAutobiographyFull: "**Wings of Fire**" (1999) is his inspiring autobiography, recounting his humble beginnings and his journey to becoming a renowned scientist and the President of India.
en.apjKalamWikipedia: ЁЯУЦ A.P.J. Abdul Kalam on Wikipedia
